page.title: 13Cider making in Street
page.content: An interview with{Mr.Hecks,}a{Street {cidermaker. Mr.Hecks}and his two sons,run a small cider business which was started by his{grandfather,}then the{landlord of Street Inn,in 1896.} He works long hours from September to January,making sweet,medium and dry cider from cider apples called {Yarlington Mill,Dabinet,Taylor's {Bitter and Kingston Black.}The apples are chopped to pulp in a mill,the flat pieces{(cheeses)}twelve at a time,are wrapped in cloths,wheeled by trolley along rails to an{hydraulic press}and crushed for half an hour.The juice runs into a tub,is pumped electrically into a barrel and left to{ferment}for {six weeks.}The{residue (pomace)}is sold for cattle feed.A{hydrometer tests when the cider is ready and then it is stored in a cool cellar for four months before selling it to the{public
